# Employment Analysis: UK Citizen as Marketing Manager – Italy vs. UK

## 1. EMPLOYER TAX & COST COMPARISON

### Option A – Direct Employment in Italy

| Cost item | Approximate rate |
|---|---|
| Gross salary | Base |
| INPS employer contributions (social security) | ~30-32 % of gross |
| INAIL (work-injury insurance) | ~0.3-0.7 % (office roles) |
| TFR (severance accrual – *Trattamento di Fine Rapporto*) | ~6.9 % of gross (≈1 month/year) |
| Other mandatory costs (13th & 14th month pay, holiday accrual, etc.) | Built into the gross annual package |

**Total employer cost ≈ 140-145 % of net-equivalent gross** (i.e., for every €100 of gross salary, the company pays roughly €40-45 on top).

### Option B – Employment through UK Subsidiary + Cost Recharge

| Cost item | Approximate rate |
|---|---|
| Gross salary | Base |
| Employer National Insurance Contributions (NIC) | 13.8 % on earnings above £9,100/yr (Secondary Threshold, 2024-25) |
| Employer pension auto-enrolment (minimum) | 3 % of qualifying earnings |
| Apprenticeship Levy (if UK payroll > £3 m) | 0.5 % of total UK payroll |
| No equivalent of TFR or 13th/14th month | — |

**Total employer cost ≈ 117-120 % of gross.**

Then the UK subsidiary invoices (or allocates via intercompany agreement) the cost to the Italian parent. The Italian parent deducts the management fee/recharge for IRES/IRAP purposes, **provided**:

- The recharge is at **arm's length** (transfer-pricing rules, Art. 110 co. 7 TUIR & OECD TP Guidelines).
- There is a proper **intercompany service agreement** documenting the nature and benefit of the service.
- The mark-up (if any) is benchmarked.

> ⚠️ **IRAP note**: The intercompany recharge is deductible for IRAP only if classified correctly (service cost, not as "costo del personale distaccato" – see Cass. 8834/2022 and recent Agenzia delle Entrate guidance on secondment vs. service).

### Preliminary Verdict on Pure Employer Cost

**The UK route is significantly cheaper on social contributions alone (~17-20 % vs. ~40-45 %).** Even after adding transfer-pricing compliance costs and a small arm's-length mark-up, the UK option usually wins on a cash-cost basis.

---

## 2. "DIRIGENTE" (MANAGER) QUALIFICATION – ITALY vs. UK

### 2.1 Italy – *Dirigente* Status

Under Italian law, a **Dirigente** is the highest employee category (above *Quadro*, *Impiegato*, *Operaio*). If the Marketing Manager is classified as *Dirigente* under the applicable CCNL (most likely **CCNL Dirigenti Industria** or **CCNL Dirigenti Commercio**), the following special rules apply:

| Feature | Impact |
|---|---|
| **Minimum salary** | CCNL Dirigenti Industria: *Trattamento Minimo Complessivo di Garanzia* (TMCG) = €75,000/yr gross (2024) for Dirigenti Commercio it is lower (~€50,000) |
| **INPS contributions** | Calculated on a **higher ceiling** (€119,650 for 2024 for the "eccedente" band); employer rate stays ~23-24 % IVS + minor funds |
| **Supplementary pension & health** | Mandatory enrolment in **FASI** (health fund – Dirigenti Industria) or **FASDAC** (Dirigenti Commercio); employer cost ~€4,500-6,000/yr. Mandatory **PREVINDAI** (supplementary pension) – employer contributes up to ~€4,800/yr (on salary up to €180k) |
| **Dismissal regime** | Dirigenti are **excluded from the standard unfair-dismissal protections** (Art. 18 Statuto Lavoratori / D.Lgs. 23/2015 "Jobs Act"). Dismissal must still be *giustificata* but remedy is **indemnity only** (no reinstatement). CCNL sets supplementary indemnities (up to ~18-24 months depending on seniority). |
| **Notice period** | Long: 6-12 months depending on seniority (CCNL Dirigenti Industria). |
| **Non-compete** | Enforceable but must be paid (Art. 2125 c.c.); for Dirigenti the consideration must be proportionate – case law requires meaningful compensation (often 30-50 % of annual gross for the restricted period). |
| **Trial period** | Up to 6 months. |
| **Working time** | Dirigenti are **exempt from maximum-hours limits** (Art. 17 D.Lgs. 66/2003) – no overtime pay obligation. |

#### Is *Dirigente* classification mandatory?

Not necessarily. The label "Marketing Manager" does not automatically mean *Dirigente* under Italian law. Classification depends on **actual powers and autonomy**, not the job title. If the role:

- reports directly to the CEO/Board,
- has autonomous budget authority and strategic decision-making power,
- supervises a significant team,

then *Dirigente* is likely the correct classification. If the role is more operational/middle-management, **Quadro** (middle-manager) status may be appropriate – with significantly lower mandatory costs (no FASI/PREVINDAI, lower notice periods, standard dismissal protections apply).

### 2.2 UK – "Manager" Status

UK employment law **does not have an equivalent statutory category** of "Dirigente." A Marketing Manager is simply an **employee** (as opposed to worker or self-employed). Key points:

| Feature | UK position |
|---|---|
| Minimum salary | Only the National Minimum/Living Wage applies (£11.44/hr for 23+, 2024) – no sector-specific manager minimum |
| Pension | Auto-enrolment: 3 % employer / 5 % employee (minimum) |
| Dismissal | Standard unfair dismissal rights after **2 years' service**; no special regime for managers |
| Notice | Statutory minimum: 1 week per year of service (max 12 weeks). Contractual notice can be longer. |
| Working time | Can opt out of the 48-hour weekly limit (individual opt-out); no automatic exemption for managers |
| Health insurance | No mandatory private health fund (NHS covers everyone) |

**Key takeaway:** The UK has **no additional mandatory employer costs or obligations** linked to managerial status. This is a significant simplification and cost saving compared to Italy's *Dirigente* regime.

---

## 3. IMMIGRATION / RIGHT TO WORK IN ITALY (POST-BREXIT)

Since **1 January 2021**, UK citizens are **third-country nationals** for EU immigration purposes. The employee **will need authorisation to work in Italy**.

### 3.1 Pathway: EU Blue Card (*Carta Blu UE*) – Recommended

Since the role is a **highly qualified** position (manager-level, presumably with a university degree and salary above the threshold):

| Requirement | Detail |
|---|---|
| **Qualification** | University degree (at least 3 years) **or** 5 years of relevant professional experience (post-2023 reform, D.Lgs. 152/2023 transposing Directive 2021/1883) |
| **Salary threshold** | ≥ 1.5× the average Italian gross annual salary. For 2024 this is approximately **€24,789 × 1.5 ≈ €37,184** (easily met for a manager role). *Note: for shortage occupations the threshold is 1.0×.* |
| **Employer obligation** | File a **nulla osta al lavoro** (work authorisation request) with the *Sportello Unico per l'Immigrazione* at the local Prefettura. |
| **Quota system** | EU Blue Card is **outside the annual *Decreto Flussi* quotas** – no cap. |
| **Processing time** | Typically 30-90 days for the nulla osta; then the employee applies for the entry visa (Type D) at the Italian consulate in the UK, then within 8 days of arrival applies for the *permesso di soggiorno* (residence permit). |
| **Duration** | Initially 2 years (renewable); after 5 years → eligible for EU long-term resident status. |
| **Family** | Spouse and children can join (family reunification). |

### 3.2 Alternative: *Nulla Osta* + Standard Work Visa (within *Decreto Flussi*)

If the Blue Card requirements are not met, the standard route applies, **but** this is subject to annual quotas and is less predictable. For a managerial hire, the Blue Card is almost always preferable.

### 3.3 Intra-Company Transfer (ICT Permit)

If you choose **Option B** (UK employment + assignment to Italy), and the employee is sent to Italy for a **temporary intra-corporate transfer**, you could use the **ICT permit** (D.Lgs. 253/2016, implementing Directive 2014/66/EU):

| Feature | Detail |
|---|---|
| Eligible categories | Managers, specialists, trainee employees |
| Requirement | Employed by the UK subsidiary for **at least 3-6 months** before transfer (3 months for managers) |
| Duration | Up to **3 years** for managers |
| Quota-free | Yes |
| Social security | Can remain in UK social security system (but no bilateral UK-IT agreement post-Brexit → see below) |

> ⚠️ **Post-Brexit social security:** The EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA) includes a Protocol on Social Security Coordination. Under it, a worker **posted** from the UK to Italy can remain in the UK social security system for up to **24 months** (with possible extension). You would need a **certificate of coverage** from HMRC. After that period, Italian social security applies.

### 3.4 Documents Checklist (if employed directly in Italy)

1. **Nulla osta al lavoro** (employer applies at Prefettura)
2. **Type D work visa** (employee applies at Italian consulate in UK)
3. **Permesso di soggiorno** (residence permit – applied for within 8 days of arrival at the local *Questura* via post office kit)
4. **Codice fiscale** (tax ID – obtainable at the consulate or Agenzia delle Entrate)
5. **Registration with the *Anagrafe*** (municipal registry)
6. **Enrolment in the SSN** (national health service) – once resident

---

## 4. STRATEGIC SUMMARY & RECOMMENDATION

| Factor | Italy (Direct) | UK (Subsidiary + Recharge) |
|---|---|---|
| **Employer social cost** | ~40-45 % on top of gross | ~17-20 % on top of gross |
| **Dirigente mandatory costs** | FASI, PREVINDAI, high notice, TMCG | None (no equivalent category) |
| **Dismissal flexibility** | Indemnity only (no reinstatement) but expensive (up to 24 months) | Standard unfair dismissal (after 2 yrs); cheaper |
| **Immigration complexity** | EU Blue Card needed (manageable, quota-free) | No visa needed to work in UK |
| **Transfer pricing compliance** | N/A | Required (intercompany agreement, documentation) |
| **Permanent establishment risk** | N/A | Low if properly structured, but if the employee acts in Italy with authority to bind the company, the UK subsidiary could create an Italian PE (Art. 162 TUIR / Art. 5 OECD Model) |
| **Employee tax residence** | If living in Italy > 183 days → Italian tax resident; taxed on worldwide income in Italy | If living in UK → UK tax resident; PAYE applies |

### Recommended Approach

**If the employee will be physically based in Italy (which is typical for a brand Marketing Manager operating in the Italian market):**

**→ Option B (UK employment + ICT/secondment) is more cost-efficient in the short-to-medium term**, provided:

1. The employee has been (or can be) employed by the UK subsidiary for at least 3 months first.
2. You obtain an **ICT permit** (quota-free, up to 3 years for managers).
3. You keep him in the **UK social security system** for up to 24 months under the TCA Protocol (saving ~20+ percentage points vs. Italian INPS).
4. You have a **robust intercompany service agreement** at arm's length.
5. You monitor **PE risk** carefully – the employee should not have authority to conclude contracts in the name of the Italian company (or if he does, this must be managed).
6. After 24 months, if Italian social security kicks in, reassess whether to convert to direct Italian employment.

**If the employee will be based in the UK** (working remotely for the Italian brand):

**→ Option B is clearly preferable** – no Italian immigration issues, lower costs, simpler administration. Just ensure proper TP documentation for the recharge.

---

### ⚠️ Key Risks to Monitor

- **Italian tax residence of the employee**: If he lives in Italy > 183 days/year, he is an Italian tax resident regardless of where the employment contract is. Italy will tax his worldwide income (with credit for UK taxes paid). This doesn't change the *employer* cost analysis but affects the employee's net pay.
- **Permanent establishment**: An employee in Italy who habitually exercises authority to conclude contracts on behalf of the UK subsidiary can trigger a deemed PE in Italy (Art. 162(6) TUIR), exposing the UK subsidiary to Italian corporate tax on attributed profits.
- **Substance over form**: Italian tax authorities (and INPS) may recharacterise the arrangement as an Italian employment relationship if the employee is de facto integrated into the Italian company's organisation, takes instructions from Italian management, and works exclusively for the Italian entity. This could trigger retroactive INPS contributions + penalties.

---

*This analysis is based on 2024 legislation and rates. I recommend involving an Italian labour lawyer (for the Dirigente classification and immigration) and a cross-border tax advisor (for transfer pricing and PE analysis) before finalising the structure.*
